comments:
I'm going to really struggle to give you a reliable test case here, but here 
goes...

In M8 (and not in any other 3.0 I or M build that I've tried), I have found 
that Eclipse stops building files. I have yet to determine whether this is due 
to length of use, multiple projects, or just some internal state failure.

Nothing obvious is reported in the .log file, although I do have multiple 
entries like this:

!ENTRY org.eclipse.ui.ide 4 4 Apr 04, 2004 23:03:08.109
!MESSAGE Error accessing marker type
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.resources 4 376 Apr 04, 2004 23:03:08.109
!MESSAGE Marker id: 68785 not found.


The essential problem manifests itself thus (in my situation):

You have a multi-project workspace, with a modest amount of interdependencies 
between projects. You edit and build (using autobuild, but this also happens 
to a colleague of mine using manual builds), and eventually the builds stop 
happening.

The fact that the builds aren't happening is evident because
a) The progress monitor stops displaying ongoing build activities
b) Coding warnings/errors fixed do not disappear from the Problems view
c) There is no noticeable build activity going on (no disk activity, no 
refresh of Problems view, no decoration changes in Package Explorer etc)

Invoking Clean does nothing; turning off autobuild and manually invoking Build 
All does nothing

The only solution is to close and restart Eclipse. Things then return to 
normal for a little while.

This is a prevalent problem - to the extent that I essentially consider M8 
unusable.

To reiterate, this appears to be a new problem. I have tried all 3.0 milestone 
builds, and quite a few of the integration builds, and have never seen this 
previously
Moving to platform for further investigation.

As you're the first to report this, and many are using M8, I suspect a localized
problem.  First, can you give more details, including:

 - What plugins do you have installed outside the ones included in M8?
 - Are these plugin projects, or just normal Java projects?
 - Are the projects shared in a repository (CVS or otherwise)
 - Anything special about your file system (network drive, samba, etc)

If you can reproduce with any frequency, you can instrument the build mechanism
to find out if builds are running:

1) Copy the file plugins/org.eclipse.core.resources_3.0.0/.options to the
Eclipse install directory (eclipse/.options).

2) Turn on builder instrumentation flags:

org.eclipse.core.resources/debug=true
org.eclipse.core.resources/build/failure=true
org.eclipse.core.resources/build/invoking=true
org.eclipse.core.resources/build/delta=true
org.eclipse.core.resources/build/needbuild=true

3) Start eclipse with the "-debug" command line argument, and use java.exe as
the VM instead of javaw.exe:

 eclipse -vm d:\java142\jre\bin\java -debug

-> You should now get diagnostics printing in the Java console.  When it gets
into a state where builds no longer happen, see if any diagnostics are generated.

I would be delighted to hear that it was a localised problem, however as it 
occurs on at least 3 machines that I know of, my hopes aren't high.

I will perform the debugging steps that you suggested, and in the meantime, in 
answer to your questions:

- I have no other plugins loaded at this time. I started using M8 from a brand 
new workspace, with a clean, full SDK installation
- All projects in my workspace are Java only
- The code for all projects is held in a CVS repository, which I access via 
Eclipse
- My work machine is a dual-processor, dual-monitor Dell running XP Pro, my 
home machine is a single-processor, single-monitor P4 clone running XP Home.

These are both machines that I have run all of the other milestone builds on 
without this problem.

My workspace has 24 projects in it - with a modest amount of inter-dependency 
between them (nothing too complex, but each is dependent on at least one other)

Thanks for all the details.  Sorry to ask this probably stupid question, but are
you sure it isn't building?  Builds now happen in the background, and the
progress shown to the user when a build starts and completes is almost
non-existent (see for example bug 52617). When no build is required and you hit
Ctrl+B, build is instantaneous and there is not even a flicker of feedback in
the UI. We are working on improving this...

Not a stupid question to ask at all :)

In trying to prove that I wasn't just imagining this problem, I set about a 
sort of experiment.

The projects I'm working on have, over time, acquired a bunch of compiler 
warnings (non-externalised strings, missing Javadoc etc), and last weekend I 
set about resolving them.

All began well - I'd correct some issues, save the file(s) and the warning 
indicators and Problem view would update to reflect that those conditions had 
been resolved. All of this was accompanied by noticable activity in the 
Progress view

After a while, however, the warning indicators, Problem view and Progress view 
all stopped responding. Essentially all signs point to the build not being 
done.

Having said that, I'm not too blinkered to admit that it might be something 
else - and had discussed this with a colleague.

What clinches it for me, though, is that when I have got into this situation 
with compiler errors (not warnings) then I get "unresolved compilation error" 
problems when I run my classes. So it does seem like it is not building.

That being said, I want to get this resolved more than any other issue, so I'm 
off to do some further experimentation!

Well, the best thing is to run with the trace options turned on as I describe.
That should print more information than you ever wanted to know about
if/when/what builds are happening.

I noticed you entered a very similar bug about builds not working in M8 (bug
56708). Is this the same situation? Are you always getting the build up of
"Running Operation" tasks before the builds fail?  Just trying to gather clues...

Yes, well spotted :)

I do get that, continually - for example, if I check out a project from CVS 
and then open the project properties to complete the dependency configuration.

It's difficult to know if the two problems are related or not. The symptoms 
are the same, but in the other issue (56708), there is a build up of entries 
in the Progress view, and in this one, there is not.

The nett effect is the same, though - it works as it should for a while, and 
then stops.

I find the other issue (56708) *very* easy to recreate. Open the progress 
view, check out a project, progress view shows stuff and then empties. Open 
properties and add (for example) an external jar library as a dependent, close 
properties to allow Eclipse to do its rebuild, and ta-da - a hanging entry is 
left in the progress view. 

After a 'random' number of these happening, no further auto-builds take place -
 eg a compilation problem that would be fixed by adding a dependent to the 
project no longer resolves when I do so.

It would be very handy if this was related, because it (56708) is much more 
predictable and easy to see :)

*** Bug 57936 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Ok, to recap what we know:

When autobuild is turned on, it stops working after some period of time. No
errors appear in the log, and tracing shows that the builders are no longer being
called at all. When autobuild is turned off, it continues to work normally.
Sometimes this happens after a build up of "Waiting: Running Operation" entries
in the progress view, but not in all cases. At least two people have experienced
this.

I'm still stumped, but I have some more questions that might help narrow it down
(theoretically after twenty questions it better be solved <g>):

1) When you get into this state, do other things that use the progress view
still work? For example, do CVS operations and Java Search still work? These
background tasks all use a common infrastructure so this might help narrow the
problem.

2) When in this state, can one of you do a Ctrl+Break in the java console (run
with java.exe as described in comment #2).  This should produce a stack trace of
all currently executing threads.  Copy this stack to a file and attach to the
bug report (see the "Create a New Attachment" link at the top of the page).

3) What VM are you using? Do java.exe -version and attach the output.

1. Trying something like a CVS "Show in Resource History" still works, but the 
Progress view reports nothing during the process. I even switched the Progress 
view to "verbose", but still nothing reported. Ditto with Java Search - the 
function works, but the Progress view does not display any activity

2. Thread dump is about to be attached

3. I am using J2SDK 1.4.2_04 - specifically:
java version "1.4.2_04"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2_04-b05)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2_04-b05, mixed mode)

Reading the report identified as a duplicate of this one, let me report this:

Now I have a workspace setup in which this happens, it can no recur in 
virtually no time at all - maybe <5 mins with only half-a-dozen or so 
successful save/builds.

This is on a workspace with multiple project in it, if that might make a 
difference.

The situation occurs regardless of whether the build would succeed, fail, or 
produce warnings.

Doing a dir of the .java and .class files shows (as well as all the other 
evidence) that the .class files are unchanged and out of sync.

Although I do have (and have reported) an issue where the Progress view 
acquires non-terminating entries (items get added and do not get removed), 
this - for me - only happens on initial workspace creation - not during the 
normal edit/build cycle, so I'm not sure if that is related.

Wow, the thought plickens...

So once you are in this state, no background operations report progress in the
progress view at all?  Try a longer running CVS operation, such as clicking
"Synchronize" in the Synchronize view. The resource history is fast enough that
it doesn't always show progress.

I currently have two Eclipse instances running. One where autobuild is still 
functional, and one where it is not.

The one that is still working (only has a couple of projects in it) generates 
stuff in the Progress view on build (auto and manual), CVS and Java Search

The one that is not working (masses of projects) generates no Progress view 
output for either auto build (cos it doesn't do anything!), manual build 
(which seems to work), CVS or Java Search (both of which work as normal)

As the broken one has wayyy more projects in it, I would have expected more 
(or at least longer-lasting) Progress view output from it...

The little 3-bar ProgressBar (bottom-right of desktop) behaves sensibly during 
long operations (build/search/CVS)

Synchronise produced no Progress view output either - although the operation 
itself worked

This is even with Verbose turned on in Progress view

**RED HERRING ALERT**

This may have *nothing* to do with it, but I'm just wracking my brains now...

In the most recent incident of this happening to me, the task I had just 
performed was to launch the code I was writing.

I've checked, at the code is no longer running and as far as I know, was not 
running on the first rebuild after that - just thought I'd mention it... :)

Ok, last question for the day.  In the Workbench > Work in Progress preference 
page there is a slider bar that is used to give an indication of your machine 
speed.  Have you touched this slider bar? If you get into a state where builds 
no longer work, does it have any effect to slide this bar all the way to the 
right (Fast)? This preference is used to throttle the amount of background 
activity that happens concurrently, so that for slow machines we don't thrash 
too much. I'm reaching here, but a bug in this computation could prevent 
background operations such as auto-build from running.

I have entered bug 58407 for the IndexOutOfBoundsException in the console 
output. I'm fairly sure this is unrelated.

Running in a different time zone to you, so apologies for not getting back to 
you earlier :)

on a different 'speed' to see if it has any impact.

I appreciate you sticking with this. I know this doesn't seem to be a problem 
that many people have noticed, but it is a major issue to us - and I'd hate to 
have it persist into 3.0 final release before others start to spot it!

In the .options file in the eclipse install directory. See comment #2.

Could you both try running with the patch found at:

http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-core-home/downloads/patches/3.0M8/runtime.jar

eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime_3.0.0/runtime.jar with the one at that
link. I recommend keeping a copy of the old JAR just in case. This patch will
only work with 3.0 M8 (any operating system).

I'm still baffled at what might be causing it, but this patch adds several extra
checks to the code that decides if another background thread needs to be
allocated (and tries to correct any error condition). This will tell me whether

related to this bug.  As we are getting very close to the 3.0 release, we need
to know if anyone can reproduce this problem on a newer build.  All components
have put in a lot of effort to produce a stable integration build this week in
lieu of the old M9 milestone.  If you could take this new build (I20040506), and

Until a reproducible case is discovered on I20040506 or later, I am downgrading
the priority of this bug.  "P1" means we will not ship Eclipse 3.0 until the
problem is fixed, which we cannot promise without knowing for certain if the
problem still exists.

With great drama, I believe we have identified and fixed this bug, within
minutes of the first Eclipse 3.0 candidate build! 

Sleeping jobs are inserted into a priority queue, and worker threads "peek" at
the queue to see if the first job should start running. There was a condition in
which a job could have its wake priority changed without the queue being
reshuffled. This could result in a job with a distant future wake time to be at
the head of the sleep queue. Worker threads would peek at this job, and then
give up after observing that the wake time had not yet been reached. Meanwhile,
other jobs further back in the sleep queue could be well past their wake time.

The fix was to ensure the sleep queue is always resorted when a job changes it
desired wake time (this was happening in most cases, but in one case it was missed).

Ian's recent debug trace showing a load of SLEEPING jobs tipped us off that some
jobs were sleeping that should have already run. Thanks to Ian for giving us
this timely information!

The fix made it (just barely) into the noon EDT 3.0 RC1 build. This build is
running now and will be available within the hour. If people experiencing this
problem could move up to this new build, it would be greatly appreciated.

For those who have not yet tried a build from today, it is probably better to
wait for the 8PM EDT build. It will contain a fix for another critical bug (bug
64540).

The 8PM build, however, will be good, or your money will be refunded :)

I will keep this bug open until I receive independent verification (aka a thumbs
up from Mr. Brown).

I still see this in RC1.

Please notice the dump of the job manager in comment 57 and comment 65. It's 
similary for me. The first item is always "Decoration Calculation" which is 
sleeping and all other jobs (building etc.) are sleeping, too. After canceling 
the first task ("Decoration Calculation"), all things start working fine again.

Note that after enabling "Verbose" mode in the Progess view I have to close 
and reopen the view to see any changes.

I think there are two possibly unrelated problems:

1) Progress view showing stale entries
2) A rare condition that causes jobs to remain indefinitely in sleeping state.

We have seen several reports of 1), although not nearly as severe as what Ian
observes. 2) needs further investigation.

Interesting thought!

On all machines that I know have experienced this problem are dual processor.

(apart from my home machine, but that is a hyperthreaded one which appears to 
the OS as a dual processor).

If this is a threading/timing issue, this may be significant...???

Same for me. HyperThreading CPU (P4 2,8 GHz) that simulates 2 CPUs for Windows 
XP.

I haven't seen this problem since I switched to RC1 yet.  However, I too am 
using a dual processor.

Well, that's certainly interesting news. The only member of the Eclipse team
facing similar problems is also using a dual-processor Windows box. I use a
dual-processor Linux box and have not seen the problem. Timing problems and
concurency bugs are often exacerbated on dual processor machines because the VMs
are more aggressive about making use of thread-local caches. I will review the
code again with this in mind.

Ines has seen similar problems on the Mac in RC1. Ines can you provide details 
please?

Unfortunately, I was not able to reproduce the "Error accessing marker type"
issue. But here are my steps if it helps:

I am using build id 200406040800 on Mac OS 10.3.3.

- Check out "org.eclipse.ui.carbon"
- Wait for the build to finish. Once the errors appear in the problems view, go
check out "org.eclipse.swt"
- Run the operation in the background
- Switch to the "Navigator View"
- As soon as you see the "org.eclispe.swt" project appear, rename SWT's
classpath_carbon to classpath
- The progress dialog shows up (showing the CVS operation and refactoring jobs)
- When both jobs were finished, I noticed that the errors were not gone in the
problems view, but they were gone in the java file
- Clicking on the errors in the problems view generated the "Error accessing
marker type" message in the log
- Re-building would not respond
- I had to restart for everything to rebuild

Just as a potentially useful hint, the last few times that this has happened 
to me, the topmost item in the 'jobs' list (from John's Jobs plugin) has been 
Decoration Calculation

This might mean nothing - I don't know if the list is in any particular order -
 but it would be remiss of me not to mention it if it gives you a clue...
*** Bug 63800 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

For those still experiencing this in 3.0 RC1, there is a chance that the fix for
bug 66168 is related to this. I'm not optimistic at this stage, but I would
encourage everyone to try 3.0 RC2 when it comes out tomorrow to see if the
problem still happens.
*** Bug 67594 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Created an attachment (id=12693)
New diagnostic plugin zip

The attached zip contains an improved plugin that will print more diagnostic
information about the state of the job manager. The Job > Dump Job Information
action will print a bunch of information on the Java console. If anyone gets
back into the state where jobs are not running, this dump information would be
very useful to see. As a bonus, this plugin also contains an action, Job > Wake
up Jobs, that should get you out of this broken state. I would be very keen to
hear if this works for those having this problem. At the very least it should
be a band-aid that helps people keep working until we have a real fix
available.

Ian, and others still experiencing this problem: I believe we have just fixed
it. See bug 68452 for more details.

We are fast approaching the 3.0 build, so we're looking for as many verifiers as
possible. The fix will appear in today's 4PM EDT build. This build is likely to
be the final Eclipse 3.0 release (with the exception of documentation changes).
If you could all run with this build, and follow up here with results, that
would be *greatly* appreciated. Hyperthreading and dual-processor results would
be particularly interesting. I will mark this fixed next week if I hear no
negative results on today's 4pm build or the final Eclipse 3.0 release.
The behaviour described in Bug 67594 seems to be corrected in 3.0 release.

I am marking this fixed in release 3.0, since we have not heard reports
otherwise. Thanks to everyone for providing the details that helped us track
this problem down.
